FEATURE: support status 429 from server and Retry-After header

cause server is overloaded, this allows server to communicate with

on_middleware_error only for internal errors

Prior to this change, the `on_middleware_error` error handler was being invoked on all exceptions that hit this middleware, including those which come from lower-level middleware. This has the side-effect of potentially masking exceptions from the Rails application, and is surprising because `on_middleware_error` is assumed to handle only message_bus errors.

FEATURE: Ruby 2.2.0 is no longer supported as it is EOL

If you require an earlier version of Ruby use and earlier version of message bus
Typo

Only publish-trigger expiry for backends that require it

This allows the tests to assert that the preferred behaviour is for expiry to be automatic at the correct time, and that this ocurrs on compatible backends. Conversely, the tests assert that backends which require publication-triggered expiry do not auto-expire; if they gain such functionality in the future, the tests would have to be updated to reflect this, allowing us to work towards eliminating this divergence in behaviour from the tests.
Asserts that both the global and channel backlogs get expired
Describes Postgres backend's expiry behaviour in tests

Tests backlog expiry actually working

The previous tests simply asserted that the backend-specific mechanism for expiring backlogs on Redis was set up, but not that it actually worked. The test could not, then, be exercised on other backends, whose implementations of backlog expiry do not have the same behaviour as those of the Redis backend.

These tests now assert the behaviour of the Redis backend, but do not invoke any private APIs specific to Redis, and can thus be applied to other backend implementations.
Tests storage reset recovery for all backends

Reduces duplication in backend specs

These specs were all being applied only to specific backends. Several of them are (functionally) the same, and do not need to be maintained separately. Those tests which do not apply to all backends are now clearly indicated by calling `test_only [some backend(s)]`, forming a todo list for building feature parity.

Makes forking spec simpler and less flaky

This test was introduced in https://github.com/SamSaffron/message_bus/commit/9c16e7ebaafaf2a3933a84fa1c517c0eba44b052 . Its purpose does not appear to be to assert that the forked process has a subscription (since no code is present to ensure that delivery ocurrs to both processes), nor does the order of publication or delivery appear to be important in this spec. All we're really interested in asserting here is that publications before a fork, from the forked process, and from the original process after the fork ocurrs, all get published and delivered. This change expresses that case much more simply.

Prior to this change, this test would fail on Redis approximately 20% of the time. With this change, it did not fail at all in 30 executions.
Re-opening file descriptors is not material to this spec
There is no point asserting before the child process exits

Test for recovery from backlog expiry

We were testing from recovery from a full flush, but it is also possible for a backlog to expire while message ID counters persist.

Merge pull request #140 from kubakrzempek/master

Handle missing ActionDispatch::Flash in Railtie

Handle missing ActionDispatch::Flash in Railtie

The middleware config in Rails app operates on a MiddlewareStackProxy which more
or less acts as a recorder of the operations that is applied over default stack
when the app is initialized, hence a regular `rescue` won't work here.

There are two cases to cover:
1. Someone already "deleted" (meaning it will be deleted in the end but it is not just yet)
   ActionDispatch::Flash from the stack
2. ActionDispatch::Flash was never in the stack

 #1 happens with Rails4 apps that are configured to be API-only or if someone
doesn't want the middleware in their stack.
 #2 is a Rails5 API-only app behaviour.

To handle either case the initializer in `MessageBus::Rails::Railtie` is looking
for both cases and applies the MessageBus middleware appropriately.
The default behaviour can be easily changed via regular Rails config block.

```ruby
 # config/initializers/message_bus.rb
Rails.application.config do |config|
  # do anything you wish with config.middleware here
end
```

Merge pull request #75 from jeremyevans/memory

Add memory backend

Add memory backend

The memory backend uses the same specs as the postgres backend,
except it doesn't run the fork or multi_process specs, since
those wouldn't work.

Only change to the lib code is returning instead of raising on
a destoryed bus.  The memory backend is fast enough that it
exposes a race condition in the rack middleware spec causing
warnings but no failures.  I think it's simpler to just
return in this case, as if the bus has been destroyed, you
don't want to keep subscribing.

Merge pull request #74 from jeremyevans/pg-fork

Make all specs run with same backend, fix PostgreSQL fork handling

This will catch errors more quickly.

Fix some specs that used the backend directly with only a single

Remove fork handling in the postgres backend subscribe

It turns out we don't need to detect forks during subscribe.
subscribe runs in a separate thread, and threads aren't copied
on fork.

In the general fork detection, don't clear listening_on, as that
will cause the subscribe in child processes to fail early. This
fixes the forking spec.

Use reset! instead of pub_redis.flushall in specs

pub_redis.flush_all is redis-backend specific.

Use configure instead of redis_config= in specs

redis_config= sets the backend to redis.  This resulted in some
of the postgres specs actually running using redis previously.

Merge pull request #72 from jeremyevans/pg

Add PostgreSQL backend using LISTEN/NOTIFY

Avoid missed notifications when using the postgres backend

In very rare cases a message could be missed when using the
postgres backend.  This happened because PostgreSQL notifications
are sent on transaction commit, which can be out of sequence with
the global ids (which are created during the INSERT statement,
before transaction commit).  Here's an example

process 1: publish "/foo", "a"
process 1: INSERT query run
process 2: publish "/foo", "b"
process 2: INSERT query run
process 2: COMMIT
process 1: COMMIT

In the above case, the message published by process 1 will have
a lower global id than the message published by process 2, but
the notification for process 2 will go out first.  Because of
the previous two-level processing of global backlog, with one
before the LISTEN and one after, the above situation could
result in a missed notification.  If process 3 is subscribed to
channel /foo and the pre-LISTEN process global backlog ends with
the notification published by process 2 (because the transaction
committed before process 1), the highest_id returned by the
pre-LISTEN process_global_backlog would be greater than the global
id published by process 1.  If process 1 commits before process
3 LISTENs, the post-LISTEN process_global_backlog will miss the
message published by process 1.

The simplest solution is just to only proces the global backlog
post-LISTEN.  It would be possible to process the global backlog
pre-LISTEN and record any missing ids, then also check for those
ids post-LISTEN, but that's a more intrusive change.

Better testing in multi_process_spec

Keep track of all responses.  If an expected response was not
received, post which one, and if an unexpected or duplicate
response was received, also post that.
Remove unnecessary sleep call in spec

Fix thread safety issues

The important fix here is always deleting from @allocated in the
ensure clause in hold.  Not doing so causing the thread safety
issues.

Numerous other beneficial changes while here:

* Keep references to inherited sockets, so they don't get garbage
  collected. You still need to make sure to use exit! instead of
  exit in the child processes.

* Make @listening_on a hash, and store a unique value for the
  channel.  This fixes issues if you subscribe, unsubscribe, and
  resubscribe quickly.

* Add exec_prepared method which automatically calls clear on the
  PG::Result objects returned by PG::Connection#exec_prepared. This
  cleans them up as soon as they aren't needed, as opposed to
  waiting for GC.

* Use separate connection for LISTEN, instead of a connection from
  the pool.  This can fix issues if trying to use the same bus
  inside the yielded messages.

* Add better fork detection to hold and subscribe.

* Remove queue in memory stuff, since it appears to be tied to
  Redis specific code.

* Don't use a separate MessageBus::Postgres::Client connection for
  the subscribe, now that MessageBus::Postgres::Client uses a new
  PG::Connection internally.

Allow multi_process_spec to be run multiple times

This supports a MULTI_PROCESS_SPEC environment variable, specifying
how many times to run the spec.  As race conditions won't show up
on every run, you may need to run it multiple times, and this
provides an easy way to do so.  If one run fails, it skips the
remaining runs.

The other change is that after the responses have been collected,
the bus is unsubscribed normally, and the thread is joined.  This
makes it so threads aren't getting leaked.

Merge pull request #73 from jeremyevans/explicit-channels

Support passing channels to Rack middleware via env['message_bus.channels']
Remove connection from pool if there is an error in UNLISTEN

Double allowed jitter in spec

I see rare failures with both Redis and PostgreSQL with 50ms.

Support expiration of backlog

This was previously not supported by the PostgreSQL backend, only
by the Redis backend..

For high performance, it would probably be better to support a
method where clearing backlogs and expiring could be done every
10/100 requests or 1/10 minutes, instead of doing so on every
request.

Support passing channels to Rack middleware via env['message_bus.channels']

This changes MessageBus::Rack::Middleware to recognize the
'message_bus.channels' env entry as the channels to use for the
request, in preference to creating a new Rack::Request object
and using Rack::Request#POST.

This makes it easier for earlier middleware or request handler to
handle access controls for channels.  Currently, to do so would
require messing with rack.input, which is kind of a pain.

To support setting the client.seq value, that can also be specified
as the 'message_bus.seq' env entry.

There is no change to backwards compatibility if the
'message_bus.channels' env entry is not present.
Minor README tweak to be less Redis-focused [ci skip]
Rename backend spec files to match lib file names
Remove pg from Gemfile, since it is now in the gemspec

Automatically create table if it doesn't exist in the postgres backend

This makes the postgres backend like the redis backend in that
it no longer requires special setup. Other changes:

* Remove the setup!  and reset! class methods from Postgres::Client,
  and the setup! method from Postgres::ReliablePubSub, no longer
  needed.

* Make some internal Postgres::Client instance methods private.

* Correctly use a mutex in some additional cases.

* Remove flushall and flushdb instance methods.

* Use PG::Error instead of the historical PGError.

* Remove connections from the pool if there is a PG::ConnectionBad
  exception raised.

Remove redis runtime dependency from gemspec

Move it to a development dependency, and add a development
dependency on pg as well.

While here, set required_ruby_version in gemspec to 1.9.3.
MessageBus definitely does not support ruby 1.8.7 due at least to
use of ruby 1.9+ hash syntax.  I'm not sure if 1.9.2 is supported,
but since it's untested and probably unneeded, it shouldn't be an
issue.

Support testing the PostgreSQL backend on travis

Also add support for testing on ruby 2.3, and update the versions
use for testing on other ruby versions.
Remove redis-specific naming from PostgreSQL backend

Add MessageBus.configure for configuration

This adds a single entry point for configuration via an options
hash.  It changes the previous configuration methods to use
.configure internally, so it should be fully backwards compatible.

The specs are now split into spec_redis and spec_postgres tasks,
with the spec task now running both.

I changed the PostgreSQL backend to pass connection options
via :backend_options.  For backwards compatibility, I didn't modify
how the Redis backend handles options.

Backends are now stores in message_bus/backends/*.rb, allowing the
use of external backends.  The backends should register themselves
in MessageBus::BACKENDS using a backend symbol key matching the
filename, and the value being the pub sub class.

Add PostgreSQL backend using LISTEN/NOTIFY

This supports PostgreSQL as a backend.  Originally, I attempted to
just provide a replacement Redis object that duck-typed and worked
on PostgreSQL, but due to differences between PostgreSQL and Redis
I was not able to get it to reliably pass the multi_process_spec.

This adds a lib/message_bus/postgres/reliable_pub_sub.rb file
with the PostgreSQL support.  To use the support, you currently
need to require that file manually, then pass a
:pub_sub_class=>MessageBus::Postgres::ReliablePubSub option in
your redis_config.  Connection options to PostgreSQL go in a
:pg_config subhash.

One significant difference between this PostgreSQL backend and the
Redis one is the dropping of channel-specific backlog ids. The
PostgreSQL backend only stores a single backlog id, not separate
global and channel backlog ids.  I don't think the lack of a
channel specific backlog id should be a problem. As long as the
channel backlog id is monotonically increasing, no messages
should be missed.

This does make some minor changes to the specs to make them support
both Redis and PostgreSQL.  Most of the changes are simple and
self explanatory.  I did add a ensure exit!(0) to the specs that
fork.  You can't call a normal exit in these specs, as the
garbage collector messes with the database connection sockets,
you need to call exit!(0) to skip that.  I added the ensure because
if there is an exception, it will be caught by minitest, but the
specs will keep running in both the child and parent processes.

Currently, the PostgreSQL backend does not automatically create the
table for you on first use, you need to do that manually by calling
MessageBus::Postgres::ReliablePubSub.setup!, which also clears the
table if it already exists.

This PostgreSQL backend reliably passes all specs for me, and works
for me in a simple application.  However, I didn't do any testing
with it at scale.

Merge pull request #71 from jeremyevans/minitest

Port the test suite to MiniTest

Port the test suite to MiniTest

This actually uses minitest/spec.  Hopefully that's fine.

This replaces rspec with minitest in the Gemfile, and removes
the redis, rack, rbtrace, guard-rspec, and rb-notify gems from
the Gemfile.  redis and rack in the gemspec and do not need to
be specified twice, guard-rspec seems to be related to rspec,
and rbtrace and rb-inotify don't seem to be needed to run the
tests.

Merge pull request #59 from powerhome/feature/reliable-first-connection-delivery

Simple attempt at bridging message delivery race

Simple attempt at bridging message delivery race

In the case that a message is published while we're calculating the backlog, we previously missed it. If the backlog turned out to be empty, we would have begun waiting for new messages, but the published message could have been delivered to the connection manager prior to informing it of the client. This would result in the message failing to be delivered until our long-poll timeout.

This adds an in-memory backlog per client which is filled while we calculate the backlog in Redis. The combined (deduplicated) backlog is then considered for delivery, closing the gap. Any messages received between collecting the message buffer and delivering the backlog will become part of the Redis backlog response on the next request.

Merge pull request #5 from felixbuenemann/fix-js-client-timeout-error

Fix #4 js client connection timeout exception

Fix #4 js client connection timeout exception

If the server closes the connection without a reply, eg. because a
timeout was hit before the MessageBus.long_polling_interval or due to a
server restart, the success callback is called with null data.
The code no handles this gracefully instead of raising a TypeError
inside jQuery.each trying to call object.length on messages.
This case is not counted as an error, because we usually can reconnect
just fine instantly.
